Description: Fragment of inscription with a probable dedication to Apollo or a boundary marker. Smooth front face with upper and left edges preserved. The bottom side is broken off, however, a six-letter inscription in eastern Ionic script is preserved in two rows and divided by engraved horizontal lines. On a third row below it is likely to be written: ΑΠΟ / ΛΛΩ / [ΝΙ] or [ΝΟΣ]. The letter forms are vertically aligned but not regularly spaces, and deeply incised. The letter heights are 2.3 – 3.5 cm. The left side is eroded except for the smooth 2 cm wide band adjoining front the face side. The right side is badly eroded but preserving traces of letters in two rows are divided by an engraved horizontal line (possibly ΜΥΛ / Υ […]). The surface of the back is badly eroded. The origin of the marble may be Ionia.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Labelled in blue ink 'Naukratis?', no other information on findspot or acquisition history. Published in: E. Eidinow, 'An Inscription in the Basement of the Ashmolean Museum', ZPE 156 (2006) pp. 114-116; Koenigs 2007, p. 344 no. 43. Following Eidinow (p. 114 note 2), the marble most likely seems to be Ionian (Koenigs 2007, 344 Cat. 43).
Bibliographic references: Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.43, p.343.) (Phase 3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.58)
